page.title: 08THE UNION CANAL
page.content: The Union Canal was built between 1818 and 1822 and stretched 48 kilometres from Falkirk to Port Hopetown in Lothian Road, Edinburgh. The canal was built at 70 metres above sea level and it joins the Forth and Clyde Canal with a series of locks at Camelon. The engineering skills include three aqueducts crossing the Avon, the Almond and the water of Leith and also a 633 metre tunnel near Falkirk. Evidence of former use can be seen in various ways such as in grooves on bridges worn by tow ropes as horses pulled the barges. Mile markers can be spotted and former turning points can be seen in Linlithgow and Broxburn.The canal is disused although a conservation group are promoting the use of the canal for various recreation purposes.
